Parametric Flex Box written in post script. With mm, cm, inch.
More info in the instructions.
Hi, Version 1.4 is here with all the extras of V1.3.3 but without the bugs.

• New layout that uses less material
  • Finger hole to easily open the box again.
  • Hinges are different colour, so you can order what gets cut first.
    • Version 1.4 is now the current one, versions 1.4.x are experimental. Use V1.4 unless you want a buggy script, all previous version will stay on here if you want to use them. There are suggestions on var values in the Usage section. Go have fun.

Open the .ps file in you image editor (I use Inkscape), it does some magic and draws the box to the dimension in the file. As default there is no stroke to the lines so select all and set it to you colour. To change the box dimensions open the .ps file in your text editor (e.g. geany, notepad) you can then change the vars at the top of the file. More instructions in the file. Suggested min corner radius 15mm any smaller then plywood can't flex and snaps. Greater for acrylic.
This limited the smallest box you can make to about 60mm height and 60mm length. Width isn't limited(that I know of). To change the units just change x in "/unit x def" to one of the units above it (mm,cm,inch).
I didn't write this, all credit goes to Brian Dahlem (bdahlem). I am simply maintaining and updating little bits.

Tested with a 50x50x50mm box 10mm radius fits fine and to dimensions. Let me know if anything doesn't work and I'll try and fix it.
Also I am happy to try and add features
if you to use PS files in windows you will need this too: http://clownfishcafe.blogspot.co.uk/2014/05/importing-eps-files-into-inkscape.html Linux it seams to be fine.

• Removed text from the output image. Was causing Inkscape to fail with the import.
  • Changed the unit select system.
  • Added missing mul from corner radius (my bug).

• Changed line with to 0.004mm so it's visible in Inkskape on import but shouldn't cause a problem.
  • Added fingerTabs in the lid so you can get open set to 0 for no hole.
• Re-done layout so both side panels are on top. I believe it's a more efficient use of material

• Added inset for fingerTab so you can make flatter holes.
  • Setting fingerTab to 0 removes the hole from the drawing.
  • Changed color of the hinge lines to make sure you can laser them first (My laser software was cut the outside before the hinges). Hinges Red, outline Black.
• All updates above.

description.text: A simple way of mounting a DIN 35 rail to the Ultimaker 2

To make this rail you will need a piece of DIN 35.   
Simply print both corners, no support required.   
The DIN 35 rail snaps right in to the printed parts. For a more permanent and stronger attachment add glue to the printed parts before inserting the rail.   
If it proves to be useful to people then I will start working on models that makes it possible to attach rails to all sides of the Ultimaker 2 in any combination.

description.text: If cold air is dropping down from your cooker hood this device can help you out.

Print the valve on overhead projector foil sheet.
Print reduction and Clamp
Assemble with Ø3x15 screws Connect Ø150mm ventilator / Cooker hood to reduction and funnel to Ø125mm tube (measures 128mm). The sheet bends out when airflow starts and blocks the wind when stopped Isolate the smaller Ø125mm tube to prevent condense water dripping down. http://youtu.be/05isEYCXEgg
This is an RC airplane with the PowerUp 3.0 control module. The plane is very maneuverable and flies quite well! Overall a blast to print and fly. http://youtu.be/emXTTow9hcY

I covered the wing and tail surfaces with a thin plastic similar to mylar. Tissue paper or grocery bag would also work. The wings glue together into a 'V' shape (I used super glue) and the glued wing assembly can then be put into the rail in the fuselage and also also glued.  
There are two mounting clips, one in the front and one in the back, that the PowerUp clips into. You can slide it back and forth to find the right center of gravity, and then it can be secured with a wrap of black tape or a zip tie.

description.text:
I lost the knob for a random consumer electronics thing, and I thought I'd print a new one - well, you know how one thing leads to another, usually an SCAD script, in my case.
This is a snap-on knob for a shaft with a flat - there's an internal stress-relieving slot that helps the thing absorb the strain of pushing it onto the shaft.

Measure the shaft you want to slide this on - my shaft had two portions, with slightly different diameters. The flat is on the top half (!). The awkward +0.5's are a way of compensating for my Makerbot's printing holes smaller than I'd like. (But see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6118 and assorted blog post http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/02/polyholes.html) Measure or calculate or guess the height of the knurled section you want (this is the bit you hold with your fingers). Decorate the bottom, if you wish, with a skirt. For real added credibility, add a dome on the top. Don't be excessive. Enter the parameters to the beginning of the script, run it, and print the resulting stl. Have fun!

I needed another food tray for my budgies so that the one male in our flock of 4 wouldn't prevent his sister from eating.  I am hoping a second food tray will be harder for him to control.  
Safety note:

I don't know for certain which plastics are safe for birds. I suspect ABS would be OK, and PLA would be fine (depending on the dyes/pigments used). Use at your own (or your birds own) risk. Off the top of my head, the possible risks are:
  • Chemical residue (toxicity)
  • Off gassing
  • plastic splinters and shards for the birds to pull on and swallow
    • I am not a bird or plastic safety expert.

The openscad source file has a bunch of parameters, to adjust the fit for the cage.  I haven't tried to print it yet, and I may need to go back in and generate some support material for the perch bar and the back.  I haven't decided what orientation to print this in just yet.  
In order to make sure that there is really good layer-to-layer bonding, I will probably use 0.15mm or smaller layers, and lots of heat.  
I think a light sanding and a thorough washing before use is a good plan.  For ABS, I would also make sure it has a couple of days to off-gas after printing.

Why do we like cigarettes? Because of this one molecule, nicotine. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicotine I printed everything in the molecule but left the hydrogen out. It is a controversial drug because of its health risks, but many people like it. The annual sales of tobacco worldwide is still US $35 Billion (yes you read that correctly) according to http://www.worldlungfoundation.org/ht/display/ReleaseDetails/i/20439/pid/6858 I did not have a particular use of this 'thing' in mind, other than to show what nicotine looks like

comments.text: You're missing some hydrogens, there.

remixed_from.author: Ablapo
remixed_from.title: Servo direct connector (surface melt) - femur, thigh bone

description.text:
With this triangle connector you can build a robot with three servo legs. (A frame for quadrupeds is included, too.) Can it walk? I don't know, yet! :-)
Do you have ideas of a good walking method for tripods?
And it's a three finger robot claw, too! For more details on the legs:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53984 Watch this video of its static durability:
http://youtu.be/snGuxtebuYs

For this tripod you will need 9 metal geared servo motors (~12g).
Assemble each leg. Then mount the legs on the center triangle part.
The provided leg parts are optimized for servo gears with a diameter of 4.8 mm. You have to melt the inner surface of printed part using a tiny flame, to mount it on the servo gear. The part should not fit on the servo without melting it. If your servo gear's dimensions are different (>0.05 mm), then create your own version from the ancestor scad files. You can use the four M3 holes of the triangle to mount the "head" (not included).

comments.text:
Nice concept, but for the "walking" part sadly I have to say no. At least with your current foot configuration. To be able to walk you have to move the centre of the gravity between three support points to stabilise the robot (three is the most stabile contact points when you are not using sensors thus no feedback). Since you have pointy feet and only three legs a walking motion is impossible, but like many others have pointed out hopping or dragging are viable options. But if you are to keep this three legged then is you add one joint to each leg and a wider paw and also make it walk with legs nearly straight down you might be able to artificially create the triangle of contact points.
Your stability video really proved that triangle is the best support shape sadly in it every leg counts for the balance. Other thing that came to mind is that your legs are quite far from the centre of the gravity. This even more improves its a balance but makes difficult to shift the weight to the two legs since they are quite far from the optimal position.
Otherwise your approach to the problem of using feather servos as a supporting structure is splendid… and I really like the looks of it. There is just something that reminds me of some anime and game robots which for me is always a bonus. I'm really interested what kind of motions you'll come up and I wish you a great success in your endeavours!
comments.author: HuGoroN

comments.text: I love your minimalistic design! Inspiring.
comments.author: Nigete

comments.text:

comments.text: it will have to step quickly.  You will probably have more luck going straight if it lunges/hops forward off the single back leg and lands/catches itself on the front two. It's going to have to hop like a frog or rabbit.   The other option is to put wide feet on each leg so that standing on two legs will offer more stability like a cane with more than one foot.

author: mklange

description.text:
This variant of the CAT 12 V plugs & sockets is intended (a) to lock together so they can't vibrate apart with motion and vibration and (b) the plug is hooded so touching it against metal can't accidentally short circuit it. This is useful for example with a battery and a battery charger where both sides of the connection can be live. A regular CAT plug can plug int a click-lock socket, but a click-lock plug can only plug into a click0lock socket. A click-lock socket can be mounted in a wall plate but will stick out instead of being flush. (As produced on my printer they don't really "lock", but they won't vibrate apart with typical vehicle motion, either. This can doubtless be adjusted if necessary.) See all CAT Standard plastic connector designs on Thingiverse.com .
See all usage & wiring techniques in www.TurquoiseEnergy.com newsletters.

author: sin0822

description.text: hi

This is for creating 12 volt rechargeable dry cell batteries from 1.2V NiMH D cells. Small copper strips (fairly thick copper is recommended) must be bent and placed in the grooves for external and interconnections.  
Be sure you get real ~10 amp-hour D cells, not 2 amp-hour AA cells in a D cell package.  
A stack of three trays is sufficient to start a small car. In my experience the car's regular charging system makes it a drop-in replacement (1985 Toyota Tercel, 4-runner), but newer cars may be perhaps charge differently - I don't know; user beware.  
One D-cell tray plus some supercapacitors might also make a great car starter.

author: JoshyB

title: Large scale Divers watch desk clock

description.text:
If you ever wanted a really massive divers watch desk clock -
your dreams have been answered! However, this little project isn't for the faint hearted! 131 individual parts (or thereabouts).
30 hours printing time - approx @ 0.2mm
(0.1 recommended).
50 metres of filament @ 3mm dia.
400g weight (approx) This project will require model making skills and lots of patients!
Ideally, all parts should be printed at 0.1 or higher if possible and some fine tuning will be required to make parts fit. Printed on the MB Rep 2 and Ultimaker 2 Printed with Faberdashery Bling Bling Gold, Robot Silver and Classic Black PLA. Fully detailed printing spec and assembly instructions included. UPDATE: 210115
I've had a couple of requests for the face to be printable flat on the bed. You won't get the maximum resolution in that orientation but i've added a new .stl to the list: Face_dial_MB flat.stl UPDATE: 250115
I've spilt the 'Back thread' file into two individual files:
Back_thread_2_v2.stl
Back_thread_1_v2.stl
Easier to print as two individual parts - the previous file had one thread ring not on the bed - sorry about that! UPDATE: 300115
Added v2 version of the main body. Split into 2 files:
MAIN_body_1_v2.stl
MAIN_body_2_v2.stl
Simpler geometry - some users were having slicer, printer issues. UPDATE: 080215
Added v2 versions of the bracelet files:
Bracelet_outer_links_v2.stl
Bracelet_inner_links_v2.stl
Optimised arrangement to fit onto smaller build beds. UPDATE: 170215
Added a new 'Main clasp' (without support) file.
To use with your slicer support settings UPDATE: 040815
Replaced Bracelet_inner_links_v2 with a new file:
Bracelet_inner_links_v3 - some of the links weren't aligned to the floor (only an issue if slicing higher than 0.2mm) UPDATE: 081115
Added a blank face dial: Face_dial_Blank.stl. Add your own branding Enjoy!

Fully detailed instructions included with the 'Thing files':
Divers_Watch_desk_clock_v1.pdf

comments.text:
I'm guessing that your slicer is having issues slicing/recognising thin 'walls'?
All the parts you mentioned that are missing in slicer have wall section/detail thicknesses of 0.5mm or there about - for some reason your slicer isn't 'seeing' them?. Its not the layer height settings that will solve your issue, its the nozzle size, shells/walls you are specifying that will effect how you slicer deals with thin wall structure. I've never used CubePro slicer, so i can't help with that i'm afraid. But I've checked the files you mentioned in Cura, MakerWare and S3D and all slicers preview/slice the thin walls okay.

comments.text:
Update on problems printing the Main bady.
With Repetier and Cura I still have the localised problems which I am sure is due to non manifold areas. I tried sending the file (in various forms) to Nettfab only to have them say they cant do anything!
Next I tried Repetier and Slic3r (which I have not configured to my liking yet) and the results were perfect.
I tried ReplicatorG and after an hour pulled the plug as it was too slow. Cura sliced in less than a minute and Slic3r about 4 minutes.
Conclusion, There is something with this file (non manifold) which confuses Cura and not Slic3r. With other models/projects I read of other people having slicing problems whereas I do not with a similar setup. Previously other files which have been highlighted as non manifold, Cura somehow manages perect results which led me to believe the warnings were not to be taken seriously. I now know differently.
I am begining to think perhaps the PC on which different incarnations of the slicing software are also a factor which is why different folk experience different results.
Until I solve this problem production on my divers watch has ground to a halt :(

description.text: Stool that can stack on top of itself, modelled off the truncated octahedron honeycomb pattern.

Print "upside down" for best results, and scale to an appropriate size.  
This stool can stack in a somewhat regular stacking pattern (rotated 20-45 degrees), or spread out in a honeycomb pattern. The honeycomb stacking pattern is modelled off the truncated octahedron honeycomb pattern. Version 1 is not quite the same (no vertical squares, hexagons are non-planar). Version 2 is a much closer representation, but has a less dense "plain" stacking pattern (45 degree rotation).

title: Control your 12v/24v power supply with G-Code!

description.text: How about a quick-ish and cheap way to switch your RepRap power supply using G-Code instead of a manual switch (or needing to unplug it)?? Done. I have created an Instructable for you! http://www.instructables.com/id/Converting-12v24v-power-supply-to-remote-G-code-sw/
Add a relay module to your power supply and switch it with G-Code! http://www.instructables.com/id/Converting-12v24v-power-supply-to-remote-G-code-sw/

comments.text: Can you explain if and how this setup can work on a GT2560 board?
comments.author: raynoland

comments.text: Not specifically. But - you can use any addressable "pin" and assign it the same function. If you can set it high or low in the firmware, then you should be able to use it instead of the 'PS-ON' pin. The Adruino 2560 uses pin D12 for the RAMPS 1.4 PS-ON pin, which is set in Marlin.
comments.author: raynoland

comments.text: Hi, and thanks for this awesome project! I plan on implementing it to my PSU soon, and look on eBay for the relay. I see some of them are "High level trigger", and some of them are "High/Low level trigger". Which type is correct for this project, or does it not matter? Thanks!
comments.author: aherland

comments.text: It doesn't matter. The 'high-level' trigger means that the module needs +voltage to activate and 'low-level' trigger means that the module needs a ground signal to activate. You can send either by configuring the pin high or low in your software. :)
comments.author: aherland

comments.text: Thanks for the clarification. :)

author: sharkbot

description.text:
I really love Khet. It is basically laser chess with expansions. Ever since I got my 3D printer I have wanted to print something for Khet and I finally had a great idea: Teleporters. Easy to design, print, and implement.   
These are for Khet 1.0 since that is all I have, but I'm sure they could be scaled to work with 2.0 if you know the dimensions.   
Below are the rules for playing Khet with teleporters and I have uploaded images for the layouts of the standard setups with teleporters included. The images I have included for the setups are all untested except in my head. I have tried to make them interesting and sometimes require movement of the teleporters. If you find a better starting position, please let me know and I may change my recommended setup to your idea.  
If I have forgotten anything, if something is unclear, or if you run into a situation that isn't covered by the rules, please ask and I'll update the rules ASAP.

• Pharaohs (kings) may not step onto teleporters.
  • All other pieces use one turn to step onto a teleporter and are instantly moved to the other teleporter before the laser button is pressed.
  • You may not rotate a piece during the movement from one teleporter to the other except to maintain the appropriate orientation. This means that the teleporter has an UP, DOWN, LEFT, and RIGHT. The pyramid points towards the sun. The sun is UP, and the base of the pyramid is DOWN. If a mirror is facing DOWN and LEFT when a "Pyramid", "Djed", or "Eye of Horus" game piece steps on to the teleporter, it must be facing DOWN and LEFT when it lands on the new teleporter.
  • Each teleporter may be moved individually as a normal game piece if it is empty. It can be moved one space on the board or rotated 90 degrees as one turn. Either teleporter may be moved by either player as their turn, but only if there is no game piece currently occupying the teleporter you wish to move. If only one teleporter is occupied, the unoccupied teleporter may still be moved.
  • Stepping off of a teleporter is a regular move. This does not automatically happen after a teleportation. If a destination teleporter is occupied when an origin teleporter is stepped onto by another piece, swap the places of the pieces while maintaining the proper rotations of the pieces. (think ring platforms in Stargate SG-1).
  • Stacked "Obelisks" may teleport just as unstacked "Obelisks" and other game pieces.
  • A "Djed" or "Eye of Horus" may teleport or change places with a teleporter just as they would with other pieces with which they can change places.
  • When playing with a "Tower of Kadesh", teleporters may be moved up and down the tower just as other pieces would. Game pieces may of course teleport onto and off of the tower following the established rules of teleportation.
    • I think that is about it. I hope you like the idea and enjoy playing with teleporters! If you don't have Khet, please consider picking it up at your local game shop or on the internet!

It is hard to see the orientation of the teleporters in the photos. All the initial rotations are pointing away from the player closest to them. In other words, UP is always pointing at your opponent on the teleporter closest to you in the photos. The PDF file in the Thing Files section includes the rules and has better pictures of the setups.
I printed my pieces on an Ultimaker 1.0 with 100 mm/s speed, a temp of 210, and at a resolution of .2

This is Version 6.3 of my pool/pond racing outrigger! The empty hull weighs in at 62-67g depending on print, and the complete boat could weigh as little as 110g, or up to 165g. This little guy rips, and the best part? Every piece is included, except for one small push rod, one 2mm bicycle spoke, one small bolt and nut, and electronics!

Okay guys, the boat is actually really simple, and printing is the longest part! Print the sponsons and the Aft float assists completely hollow (no infill) with at least a .6mm wall thickness. If this wall thickness is not met, the will likely break when inserting the Sponson Arms. Depending on quality, and your printer, the boat can be printed in as little as 3 hours, or as long as 8+. * Parts and opening may need a bit of adjusting or cleaning up depending on your printer accuracy Construction;
1) Insert Sponson into both Tub halves, and clean up the tup opening if you have to.
2) Use medium thickness CA around the stepped area to join the two tub halves (dont forget to keep the sponson arms between the two halves, otherwise they will be very hard to insert later!). At this point the halves will be joined, and the sponson arms should be loose.
3a) These next steps can happen in any order. I prefer to glue in the aft float assists. To do so, I put a layer of CA all around the "male" insert, then along the inside (the side that will meet up with the tub) perimeter, to keep water out. Then insert that "male" pegs into the tub, and press lightly until the CA dries. Repeat for the other side.
3b) Apply CA to the opening of a sponson (do not fill it! or it will splooge!), now simply insert the sponson ALL the way until it comes to a complete stop. If the sponson is NOT inserted all the way, it may end up crooked causing a bad turning tendency. Now apply a fillet of CA around the joint to ensure it is water tight, and secure. Repeat this step for the opposite side.
4) Now your hull is almost complete. At this point all the pieces should be together, with the sponson arms still loose. Align the arms (sponson tip to sponson tip) as accurately as you can, ensuring they are straight. Tip: you can measure from the back, outer corner of one sponson, to the back outer corner of the (same side) aft float, adjust until BOTH sides measure the same. This is crucial as incorrect alignment can cause a ill-handling boat! Now that you are sure everything is straight, apply CA in a filleting fashion around the Arm and tub joint, then to the same on the other side. Note that your fillets are VERY important to ensuring the hull is water tight. 5), drill out the motor mount, and bolt in your motor. Slide the motor and motor mount into the slot provided on the tub. Now, insert your full length bicycle spoke (2mm diameter!) into the shaft guide tube, and align it with the output shaft of your motor! Accuracy is crucial or there will be a lot of drag on your motor, which could possibly burn it up! Once your are content, glue in the shaft guide tube, ensuring a water tight seal with CA. 6) Cut prop shaft to fit properly. Threaded portion is for the prop (which is self tightening) and should be at the very back of the boat. The smooth portion will be CA'd into the end of the motor adapter, with the other side of the adapter threading onto the motor (again, self tightening) The rest is pretty self explanatory. Assemble rudder, and electronics as you see fit. The provided motor to shaft adapter, is deisnged for the common prop shaft size for 250 size quad copters! If you are using a smaller motor, it is crucial that you source or make your own adapter. My set up:
Maytech 1806-2300kv motor
10A Turnigy Plush
4g 4ch Air RX
460 Mah 3s (too heavy, the boat is better the lighter it is!)
micro servo (6g)
2 blade prop If you use the same or similar power system, the drive line will work, however it may require minor modification to fit just right. BOTH props, as well as the motor adapter are SELF tightening. Locktight or glue is NOT required.

comments.text: i made one but it won't go the prop is to shallow it is getting air around the prop. i tried making a long shaft but still no luck. the motor mount needs redone to a angle that will put the prop further under water. maybe make the prop come out before the rear more under the boat? not sure how to fix this really but this as is wont work for me.
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: Neither of your suggestions will fix ANYTHING. Neither the motor mount, or shaft needs redoing, the angle is correct as well. The boat is designed to 3-point. Meaning at speed the only parts that touch the water are the aft bit of both sponsons, and the prop hub. It is a surface piercing propeller, meaning the prop is NOT supposed to be submerged. That said, it is nearly impossible (for at least my printer.) to print accurately enough to make the prop sharp enough to plane. The boat needs a gentle toss at about 40% if you have the same motor set up as me. If you switch to a new off the shelf prop, (for similar size boat, or make a new prop, not 3d printed) it works better.

description.text:
This antique car is not a specific model, but a stereotypical car from the late 1950s. I started with the general shape of the car, then added some features, such as the lights, bumper and windows.
I have always enjoyed making model cars and airplanes, so I made this as a small addition. My interest in old car models is a Ford Thunderbird that my grandfather owns. Although not operational, I hope that it will be rebuilt someday.

Upload the stl. file onto the makerbot.  I found that standing the car on its side is best, scince all the features on that side turned out alright.  The only trouble could be the wheels on the side not flush with the board.  Although they stayed attached for my car, they could be messed up.  If so, just cut off the defective wheels and make replacements, which are pretty simple.

description.text:
This library generates basic fillets using the following functions:
  • linear_fillet (straight edges)
  • corner_fillet (90 degree corners)
  • ring_fillet (cylinders - inside and outside)
  • profile (generates the 2d profile used to set the fillet shape)
    • There are more advanced fillet libraries and functions available such as the excellent:
    https://github.com/clothbot/ClothBotCreations/blob/master/utilities/fillet.scad
    however, sometimes you just need a basic fillet with a low computational overhead that can be applied quickly and easily to selected objects :)

comments.text: W00T!  I've been looking for just such a library.

description.text:
The only difference to the original is that I have turned the lamp glass into a solid model so that it can be printed with Slic3r's spiralize setting. You can get the base from the original model: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:498710 Printed in Reprapper natural PLA.
The base was spray painted in metallic gold.
The model was resized to fit a LED tea light, from Pound World.

The lamp glass was sliced in Slic3r with one perimeter with the sprialize setting, no top or bottom layers were printed. It was scaled to 180%. Printed at 220ºC, bed temperature of 60ºC for the first layer and then 80ºC for the rest. 30mm/s.  
The base was sliced in Cura with 1mm perimeters (any less and the overhangs fail), 0.6mm top and bottom layers, and 0% infill. It was scaled to 1.55. Printed at 250ºC for the first layer and 185ºC for the rest, bed temperature of 60ºC. 30mm/s.  
Post printing the base was spray painted gold with cheap (99p Stores) spray paint. Once that was dry, the LED tea light was inserted (Pound World), and the tea light, base and glass glued together with hot melt glue.  
0.4mm nozzle and e3d v6 hotend

title: Replacement and Upgrade Parts for Prusa i3 A602

description.text:
I ordered the Prusa i3 "A602" kit as found on AliExpress or Ebay. Most of the printed parts are included on the SD card. So it is easy to print replacement parts. Unfortunately, I broke the X-Endstop-Holder during the build which was made out of 2mm acrylic. So I have redrawn it in FreeCAD.  
The mounting block for the Y-idler was printed in the wrong direction by the original manufacturer and cracks were building after a short time. I had to redraw this piece also because the STL was no included.  
The third part is to be used with the spool holder that is delivered with the A602 kit. It is designed for filament spools with 75 mm center holes like the 3dfactories.com cardboard ones and the original M8 threaded rod. I printed two of these and mounted them on the rod with M8 nuts.   
As always, feel free to modify the included FreeCAD files

X-Endstop
========
0.2 mm layer height Y-Idler
=====
0.2 mm layer height, 50 % infill. Printed with support. (You may need to rotate it.)

title: Mini Cut/Print-able Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mini quad that you can 3D print, OR laser/cnc cut. I designed it specifically with one of these: http://www.amazon.com/UDI-Axis-Stablized-Quadcopter-Helicopter/dp/B0095BXACK/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1420277381&sr=8-2&keywords=udi+816 small quadcopters, however there are many other places to find the correct bits for it. It is made for 4: 7 mm diameter and 20 mm height motors and the flight controller and radio that come with them. The one in the link above is a bit over-powered, so it should fly well with frame and a micro fpv setup. I designed it with both orientations, however, you do not choose, however the board comes programmed is the one you must use. If your flight board is setup to fly with the arms extending outwards from the middle of each of its sides, use that design, if it is made for arms coming out of the corners, use that one. If weight seems to be an issue, I also uploaded versions of each orientation with slightly different legs that take up less space.
IMPORTANT: this is made to be cut out of 3 mm materials, in my case MDF or more likely acrylic sheet, any other thickness will not allow the legs to fit. The 3D printed piece is what you mount the FC in, and I did it this way so that it is easy to modify the main part for your personal setup with whichever camera and stuff.
NOTE: I have not yet uploaded versions of the actual body that are 3D as I am working on finding a good program to convert the files from 2D to 3D. If anyone has one and wants to run them through it I would really appreciate it!

Print/cut the body, mount the FC in the piece using the pegs and glue, attach whatever battery holders, covers, etc that you have added to this design, stick the legs in and superglue into place, add motors and secure with a bit of superglue as well. If you stripped another quad down like the one in the amazon link above to build this, there should be information of where to put which motors and where to connect them in its manual. Thats pretty much it.

author: loganj13

description.text: A simple AVR dragon case that allows access to all the main programming heads (JTAG, ISP, HV_PROG, VCC/GND). There is also a hole to see the LEDs.

I have been using the AVR Dragon for years without a case and thought it was time to rectify this. This simple case has a hole over the leds and two holes for access to the headers. There are no screws holding the case together I simply glued the corners together with acetone (any suitable glue could be used). It is glued on the bases that I'm not going to be replacing the dragon any time soon (use the glue sparingly so you can get it open if you want to). The top of the case holds the PCB in-place with posts in the corners. The bottom of the case has ribs in it under each side of the header positions to support the PCB when the connectors are connected. I used the following Digikey parts for connecting ribbon cable to the Dragon headers. WM8064-ND CONN HOUSNG 20POS .100" DL CRIMP
WM2561-ND CONN SOCKET 26-28AWG .100" GOLD It was printed on a MakerBot Replicator with the following setup: Object infill = 15%
Layer Thickness = 0.333mm
Number of shells = 0
Feed rate = 30mm/sec There is an stl file for the two halves printed together and one for each of the halves. Note: Care must be used when removing the top of the case from your 3D printer as it could break in two. Note: Acetone maybe be used in the assembly of this case, for those that need to be told.....Do not drink it or use it as a beauty product. Results may vary but will generally be bad.

description.text:
-- Complete rewrite of the customizable hinge is now available! It should print immensely easier for most users. I'm going to disable the customizer flag on this, though if you still want to, you can open up the scad script to customize it yourself locally. I do highly recommend switching to the new one though! Update - April 14th (2014 I think?)
--Added support material
--Options to print vertical or horizontal (though I don't think horizontal will work very well) Customizable hinge that prints all at once! You will have to break it free at first. Warning: Hinge does not come apart like many others! (unless it's only got 2 joints) More to come!
--Plans to have half-hinge and removable pin options. These will allow you to use the scad to include the hinges as part of your own creations!

• Customize to your liking
  • Print upright.
  • Take a razor around the joints
  • Firmly bend to break free
  • Enjoy!

description.text:
if you have a whiteboard, you probably know how annoying it is when you lost your marker and you need it ...
With this simple holder, your pen will never get lost !
You can screw it, stick it with double faced tape or even with a magnet if your whiteboard is magnetic. See instructions to know how to build your own diy whiteboard

How to build a simple diy whiteboard :
  • find a white wall in your house where you want to have a whiteboard
  • take a large piece of transparent plastic book cover
  • use spray glue, tape, or anything else to stick it to the wall
  • make sure you can write on it with whiteboard markers : all plastic book covers are not compatible with erasable ink.

description.text:
Check the following link. There is an improved version available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:627076 This stand covers the original G Watch R charging cradle LG SDT-330. It was made with Tinkercad. The bracelet does not bother during charging. The 28 degree slope allows to view and operate the watch easily during charging.
The main design goal for this thing was to move the wire connection to the bottom of the stand. The sphere covers the Micro USB connector. Probably not the nicest design but it can be printed with minimum support. NOTE: Read the instructions to avoid that the charging cradle is squeezed in the stand!
NOTE: This design requires glue.Dis-assembly might destroy the printed parts!

This stand consist out of two parts to allow easy printing. Enable support material.
The intake is tight. Hence you should grind the intake until the charging mount fits without effort. The whole in the middle allows to remove the charging cradle easily.
Mount the charging dock in the following order:
  • Put the charging cradle into the holder.
  • Pull the USB wire through the stand.
  • Connect the micro USB wire with the charging mount.
  • Carefully put the holder into the notch of the stand. The Micro USB connector might be a bit fractious but it shall fit into the sphere.
  • Glue the holder and stand together.
    TIP: Use a bar clamp to slightly hold the two pieces together and fix those with a small drop of superglue on the top and bottom of the overlapping notch..
    NOTE: Don't use much clue! Otherwise you have to destroy the dock for dis-assembly.
    • NOTE: Don't try to remove the charging mount without releasing the holder from the stand!

40mm sucker required
Print with brim and support, pot opening laid flat on bed A spherical micro planter for succulent, it's the size of tennis ball. Pot has a sucker holder on its back, when attached, it lies completely flush to the windows like it's floating. There are 3 other remixed version. A very special sinc(patrick) version, I don't know who did the original nerdy cartoon, but it's awesome, let me know if you (its author) feel attribution is required. The internal dimension is structured such that it's thicker at the top at 6mm (or bottom when in use), use at least 2mm top and bottom shell to ensure it finishes nicely, take a long time to print this, so 'pulls all the stops' Printed with PLA (translucent) and pain-in-the-butt ABS (orange) FreeCAD file included.

Diese Kryptex dient mir als Behälter fürs Geocachen.
Der Kryptex besteht aus fünf Ringen mit jeweils 16 möglichen Zahlenkombinationen. Die Zahlen sind frei wählbar! Der Ring und Ring_innen werden 5x gebraucht. Nach dem Einstellen der Zahlenkombination werden diese auf die Ringhülse geschoben und die Endkappe wird mit der Hülse verklebt. Aussenmasse: L=164mm, Durchmesser=70mm
nutzbares Innenvolumen: L=151mm, Durchmesser=38mm Translation from user s_mohr (thx): I use this cryptex as a geocaching container. The cryptex has 5 rings with 16 possible combinations. The numbers are freely selectable! You need to print 5x Ring.STL and 5x Ring_innen.STL After setting the combination, push the rings onto the sleeve and glue the end cap (endkappe.STL) onto the tube. Outside dimensions: 164mm long, 70mm diameter
Internal usable volume: 151mm long, 38mm diameter time to print ~ 20h 2014-05-01: added "Dose_short" for shorter time to print 2015-10-03: added: Ring_Letters (Letters A to P instead of digits 0 to 15)

author: Capelion

description.text:
I'm not sure if this is a remix as I didn't use any of Walter's 3D data to create this. Anyway, it is strongly inspired by his great creations. I needed a case with the least possible amount of elements sticking out from it's surface to keep form clean and also wanted to experiment with rubbery filaments like Ninja Flex.
This is why the lock type is designed from scratch here, to be elegant and efficient.
There are two types of file here - one suited for stiffer material like "soft PLA" or PET or even ABS and the other for more flexible ones like Ninja Flex (actually the chinese TPE was used here http://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/3-00mm-Grey-Color-NinjaFlex-Flexible-TPE-3D-Printing-Filament-1kg-spool/817624_1941979695.html ).
If you want to custmize it - I recommend using any 3d software for stretching it by moving the vertices - It's fairly straightforward...
In case you're in trouble drop me a message - I'll try to help. :)
If printing from TPE (e.g. Ninja Flex, It's good to have temps like 195-205 deg. C, speeds like 15-30 mm/s, retraction set to zero, all speeds equal (same speed for outer/inner outlines and infill).

comments.text:
Ups!.. Walter in fact does have the same lid system I used. During designing of my box I was so focused on the case type:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:386904, that I didn't notice that the one I finally refered to differs so much..
Anyway, the self-blocking profiles in the lid are the clue of my solution..

title: SMDquick Solderless Surface Mount to Breadboard Prototyping Socket for SSOP or SC70 components (0.65mm pitch,16 or fewer pins)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This was designed to replace something like this (http://www.aprilog.com/images/20SSO17-D6-ZL.jpg), the likes of which are typically sold for around $50-75 each. It can hold one component with 16 or fewer pins, or several smaller components (e.g. two 8-pin components), at once. Without modification, mine securely holds an SC70 package in place without movement or shorting, though I recommend ensuring that no pins are accidentally shorted together when inserting a component into the socket. I highly recommend that you use magnet wire (rather than standard insulated wire), both for ease of assembly and appearance (I think you'll agree that mine looks a bit ridiculous). See the instructions for more details.

Print at 0.1mm layer thickness, with support material for the overhangs of the bottom half of the assembly. I recommend printing at least two of these at a time, to allow the final layers of the print sufficient time to cool, even when using a cooling fan. No trimming or other surface preparation should be needed between print and assembly. To secure the hinge, I inserted a piece of insulated 26 gauge wire through the holes and trimmed the excess. For the pins, I used two 8-pin segments of SIP header (0.1" pin spacing), which I soldered to a 4 hole by 8 hole piece of perf-board (you can use a breadboard, as pictured, to hold them steady and perpendicular to the perf-board while doing so). The piece of SC70 PCB was cut from a larger board from my scrap pile, and was measured to be 9.56mm x 5.77mm x 1.7mm (for which I allowed 9.7mm x 5.9mm x 1.9mm in the model). In the future, it would be easier to use something like this (http://www.amazon.com/20PCS-SOP28-SSOP28-TSSOP28-Adapter/dp/B00O9YJ1US), and adapt the model to fit these (this should be trivial). I soldered the pins, one to one, using the smallest gauge wire I had on hand at the time (which I hot-glued in place to prevent any movement), though as this was vastly too large, the whole thing ended up looking like a facehugger from Alien. Insulated magnet wire of gauge 26 or higher would be much better for this, though I had just ran out. Hot-glue or otherwise secure the printed body to the perf-board. When you are done, check your connections with a multimeter or continuity tester, and ensure that you did not accidentally short adjacent pins together. Enjoy!

author: ggoss

description.text:
We are now in the midst of a 501(c)3 status approval and we couldn't be happier. Freeside Atlanta (est. 2009) is a nonprofit work space built entirely by volunteers. We are a community of makers, tinkerers, engineers, programmers, artists, teachers, and lunatics. As a community, we have built out our space with tools and equipment for electronics, 3D printing, woodworking, metalworking, art, design, classes, and events. Everything you see in our space was donated or built by members.
Our members are engaged in amazing projects and love to share knowledge. We also develop and work with open source and free technology wherever possible, and try to release our creations under variants of the Creative Commons license.
You don't have to be a Freeside member to come to our events or take our classes. We encourage you to come out to the Tuesday night Open House that we have every week at 7:30pm or to any of the other public classes or events that we have on Meetup. Come check the place out and see if this is a community that you'd be interested in joining!

Print and post pictures!  
Tuesday night and Saturdays are open house to all non-members.  Visit www.FreesideAtlanta.org for more information.

Straight and 762mm radius curve track for 32mm gauge tracks (SM32) common used in Garden railways (16mm and 7/8th scale).
The length off the tracks are made so they are printable on most 3D-printers.
There are track holders for printed sleepers och wooden sleepers.
There are STL files for complete track, track you assemble by your self and complete track for dual extruder printers.
Turnouts and other radius curve tracks are coming in the future.

It should be easy to print these tracks, you only need support on complete tracks.
You need to print 14 curved tracks for a half circle.
Dual extruder tracks aren't test printed yet, but seems Ok in Cura.
All STL files has been tested in Netfabb.
All "Dual" STL are for dual extruder print.
Templates are for easy assembly.
I have printed my tracks with PLA at 0.3mm layer height and 50% infill .

title: Arduino uno stand/holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my version of the bumper. The original holds the board in what I think odd and unpractical places and the clips where causing problems when printing (stringing causing problems).But I liked the basic design. I redesigned it from scratch to the dimensions of my Arduino Uno rev 2 (I think). The board is being held in place exactly on the four corners so it can't go anywhere. The clips are made stronger and because of the way it is designed it is easier to clean up after printing and stringing doesn't affect the critical design of the clip.
Downside of this design, It fits only original Arduino's. These arduino's have slightly rounded corners. Older Arduino's and some knock-offs don't have the rounded corners and therefor the holder won't fit. Should fit:
  • Arduino Uno
  • Arduino Leonardo
  • *Arduino YUN
  • Arduino Zero
  • *Arduino M0 Pro
  • *Adafruit Metro
  • needs to be confirmed.
    • 02/05/2014 UPDATE:
    New version (V2.0) available for download. The bumper has been made a bit more beefy. Makes it easier to print and can withstand some more abuse. 04/05/2014 Update:
    What's even better then printing one bumper, printing four in one go! I have added an .stl that will let you print four bumpers in one session. If you print this, please click the "I made one" on this thingiverse page.

printed with:
object infill: 50%
layer height: 0.2mm
Number of shells: 2
Feedrate: 80mm/s
Travel feedrate: 120
Temperature: 225

description.text:
Based on leemorton123's parametric lens cap but heavily reworked to avoid bridging and overhangs, to give a very functional lens cap. STL files are generated with diameter=76mm in order to fit a 77mm lens.  
Prints in 4 parts and clips together.  
Updated to address some issues with hole placement on smaller caps, and to try to support the online customiser.   
I had some issues getting the online customiser to work - though I hope they are resolved. If you can't get it to work in customiser, try downloading the SCAD file and making the changes using OpenScad  - but also be aware that for smaller lens caps you may need to adjust the number and/or size of the studs.

Print using your standard settings - nothing special needed AFAIK.  
Snap the caps onto the springs part, then clip into the cap and push the crossbar into place (it's a tight fit - I used a small hammer).  
For smaller lens caps you may need to set number of studs to 2 (or make them smaller - if the studs overlap you end up with a design that is not 2-manifold and cannot be exported to stl.

description.text:
There are other spool holders, but I like this design because the spool sits on top of the gantry and rotates freely. It slides in from the side, and the spool slides over the cylinder and rests, inclined slightly forward and feeds the filament down to the head.
There are two styles. One has Aluminatus branding and is larger, but holds the spool at more of an angle, where the other is small and hardly visible when in use, but still effective.

I printed the larger one with 0.1 honeycomb fill to use less filament, and the top layer did show some artifacts where it didn't close completely, but that surface is hidden inside the spool, so it doesn't matter.

description.text:
I'm trying to upload a Thing-a-day this February.
makerblock.com/2011/02/makerblock-thing-a-day/ I'm trying to create an auto-homing Cupcake CNC in an attempt to upgrade my Cupcake into a Thing-O-Matic. This "start.txt" file will allow your Cupcake to autohome. This code was essentially copied from the stock Thing-O-Matic autohoming code, but has been altered to exclude the Z homing (since I haven't designed an endstop for that axis) and does no heating of the extruder or heated build platform. Day 7: Cupcake XY autohoming GCode http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6200
Day 6: Cupcake CNC Optoendstop Trigger for X Minimum thingiverse.com/thing:6191
Day 5: Things That Cannot Be Unseen. thingiverse.com/thing:6097
Day 4: Extruder to Stepper mounting plate. thingiverse.com/thing:6106
Day 3: A shelving unit bracket. thingiverse.com/thing:6001
Day 2: A mirror bracket. thingiverse.com/thing:6000
BONUS THING: A Helen Weight. thingiverse.com/thing:6024
Day 1: A bathroom hook. thingiverse.com/thing:5999

• Install X and Y optoendstops and cables in your Cupcake CNC
  • Adjust XY autohoming GCode
  • Add XY autohoming GCode to your favorite profile's "start.txt"

Put your own image on the face of this checker and your name or message underneath.
The original is cool and mostly intact in my version, but I made so many changes that I thought I should share.
I changed the sphere to a cylinder because they were too high to stack the checkers, and I flattened out the bottom to make printing easier and accommodate the inset lettering.

You need both .scad and the letters.dxf files for this to work. You also need the cat.dxf to use my example setup. And of course you need the latest OpenSCAD. There's a lot that goes into putting a logo on top. Check out http://hackaday.com/2010/01/12/how-to-make-a-printable-ces-badge/ for an example on how the image portion works. Just put a closed line drawing centered on the origin and note the layer name. If you can't get it on the origin, just use the offset parameters to get it where you want it. Keep the drawing simple because OpenSCAD chokes on the detail. write.scad was posted by harlanDMii at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16193. I am using an older version but check out his thing if you want more information.

comments.text: Thanks for sharing the fun design. One caution - when you placed the name on the bottom of the checker, it filled in the cavity, so this piece will no longer stack with other pieces.
comments.author: RichLewis007

comments.text: I printed two sets and they all stack nicely.  In fact, there's 4 or 5 stacked up in the picture above.  If you are having trouble, you may have too much flow or the first layer is a little tight to the bed.

title: BirdsEyeView Y6 Motor Mounts for High Efficiency Propulsion Bundle

description.text: The BirdsEyeView Y6 ships with motor mounts for the standard PowerPACK motors (http://www.birdseyeview.aero/products/powerpack). If you're flying with the high efficiency propulsion bundle (http://www.birdseyeview.aero/collections/propulsion/products/high-efficiency-propulsion-bundle-prerelease) you'll find out that the motor hole spacing is different. This bundles comes with Tiger MT3506 motors and the hole spacing is larger. You can see the difference in size when comparing the white blocks with the black ones I printed. They are printed with my MakerBot R2 in PLA with 75% infill to ensure rigidity.

To me you will definitly need to cool them down.
As you could see with PLA the stepper temperature is very close to Bed temperature.
Taking that into account closing the chamber for a bed @ 110°C will get the ambiant temperature close to the bed temperature.
If you keep the enclusure closed of if you don't cool down the electronic and stepper motor part you will have some troubles i guess.

Now that I have an infant in the house who loves banging on mirrors... I figured it was time to secure it better! I've replaced the top and bottom clamps with these so they match. A spool holder design that can be used with any size spool on the market. Utilizes a 3/8" cap screw to attach a hub to the spool. Three bearings provide low friction thrust support, while tapered hub walls provide axial support. To use with a different width spool, simply buy a longer or shorter 3/8" cap screw at your local hardware store. You will need:
  • 1X 3/8" Cap Screw (length dependent on spool width)
  • 1X 3/8" nut
  • 3X Ball bearings (http://amzn.com/B009EPNW8Y)
  • 3X 20mm M5 screws (http://amzn.com/B00F32EO0W)
  • 3X M5 Locknuts (http://amzn.com/B000NBKLM8)
  • 4X #6x1/2" wood screws for mounting

comments.text: I like this design a lot, very clever work! A n observation and a question... the spools typically have raised radial ridges at least two raised concentric circular ridges. title: Wade Extruder converted to bowden for 1/8th inch pneumatic fitting

description.text:
This is a version of the wade extruder that has the hole in the bottom modified to accept the commonly used 1/8th inch x 4mm pneumatic fitting that holds the bowden tube for 1.75mm filaments.  
The fitting can be found on ebay, search "10 x Straight Quick Connectors Pneumatic Fittings 4mm x 1/8" PT Male Thread"  
It is a very tight fit, you will probably need a socket wrench with the correct socket to install it but it will be very strong when assembled.  
I put this on the top of my mini kossel and it works great.  Other parts are the same as the original wade extruder.  Enjoy!
I printed it with 3 perimeters and 50% honeycomb infill but other settings will also work.

description.text: My shot at designing a planetary gear that can be printed in one shot.  Designed parametrically in Solidworks with formula from Machinery's Handbook. title: Tracks for the Matchbox "Drott Excavator" model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tracks for the Matchbox model of the "Drott Excavator". May fit other models that use the same tread length.
I thought an "agricultural tread pattern" might look more interesting than the standard design and decided to go with it. The "sprocket wheels" on most tracked Matchbox models have ridges, but the rubber tracks lack a groove for them to run in. This has been corrected here ^^ This model needs to be printed using a flexible material (eg. PLA flex) - 30% speed at 230°C worked very well for me. Unfortunately, a prototype stuck to the build platform VERY firmly and removing it left the part with an ugly "burr" that could not be cut off easily. I therefore widened the track by one millimeter so that the burr can now be cut off with a pair of scissors without interfering with the actual tread profile. Keep this in mind while rotating the part in your slicing software.

author: P4nD3m0n1c

description.text:
This thing creates a customizable dovetail joint when can be used to securely joint two different pieces. The definitions of the parameters: Pin Depth : the depth of the Pin from the start of the chamfer to the widest part of the pin
Pin Width : the width of the widest part of the pin
Tail Height : the height of the tail block
Pin Width Fraction : 1 minus the ratio of the narrowest part of the pin (start of the chamfers) to the widest part. A value of 0.4 would result in the width of the narrowest part of the pin being 60% of the widest part
Pin Height Fraction : the ratio of the height of the pin to the height of the tail block. A value of 0.8 would result in the pin being 80% of the height of the tail block.
Overhang Depth : additional depth added to the narrow end of the pin and the back of the block
Overhang Width : additional width added to the tail block on each side of the pin chamfers
Fit Tolerance : the absolute value of the total amount to shrink the width and depth of the pin so that it will slide into the tail
Corner Trim : the absolute value of the amount of material to remove from the edges of the widest part of the pin to make the pin slide comfortably into the tail without having to drastically increase fit tolerance.
Pin Or Tail : make the pin, tail or both Best bet is to experiment with different values to see how the joint changes. The fit tolerance and corner trim works well for me for my printer and PLA - a tight fit but no filing necessary. For ABS slightly lager values of Fit Tolerance and Corner Trim are needed to get the pin to easily slide into the tail. Alternatively for ABS, I just file a little bit off the sides of the pin and it usually slides snugly into the tail.

Quickly modeled in Rhino for something fun to print.  Printed on my Prusa i3 scaled at 60%.
a simple vase created using Solidworks lofts to connect two cycloidic gear like ends. Looks great in Taulman t-glase.

Made with taulman t-glase (PETT water bottle) plastic filament. Drilled out a 0.4 mm nozzle to 0.7 mm. Sliced with Cura 14.07 with spiralize turned on and solid infill top turned off. Layer height 0.55 mm. Wall thickness 0.9 mm. The layers are intended to be highly visible. Speed 8 mm/s to give a good gloss. It still prints quickly due to thick layer height.

comments.text: Hi Sarah
comments.author: sarahndukes

comments.text: Its not new, its been around for a few years. BEWARE this is an exotic filament and it takes a lot of time to master. This guy just took settings off their main site suggestions, its not "intended" to have highly visible layers, its a result of the settings needed for a clear vase, and the layers are actually less visible here, as you may have noticed.... This guy is new too so beware advice till he learns the material. Ive been using it for over a year and you can do FAR more than this, ive began making internal layer defects on things like bridges to get better surfaces with reflective negative infill by over extruding by 0.01mm. Its a complex process, and again, beware advice from the new guys, it takes an engineer/scientist to operate these machines at a professional level. I spent 13 years, myself, on 4 degrees since 2005 during their launch to be able to get into it, a cross study of 3 different fields. It was fun but im perhaps, a little cocky now and it looses me friends sometimes. but whatever, its not my problem they feel insecure. (see what i mean? lol) ... No, but seriously, you have been warned lol. Email me if you need help ([email protected]). Ive specialized in this stuff since it was released, i even got an early sample and was the first one to ever successfully print a gear heart from tglase :D , which you'll find nearly impossible lol. A lot of the problems here are counter intuitive, like LayWooD3 so be prepared to be frustrated and lose lots of filament.

title: Gear for a Lathe's thread cutting mechanism (20 teeth, 31,9mm diameter, slot nut groove)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Of course, my lathe is missing the one gear that is necessary for cutting standard 1mm-pitch threads, and ordering a new one is not exactly straightforward - not even on the Internet.
After calculating the amount of teeth based on the information on the sticker on the lathe and playing around with my 3D modeling software for a while, I came up with this part.
Tests were very convincing; I can now cut threads with a perfect 1mm pitch again. In case anyone's interested: this is a Chinese lathe a friend is lending me, but I can't remember the exact manufacturer's name and model. I'll update the part with this information if desired.

author: Capelion

title: Face Plate for Philco C4608 Auto Radio

description.text:
This radio face plate is for a Philco C4608 Auto Radio (Mopar Model 802).  Designed in Inkscape using a photo enhanced and thesehold adjusted with GIMP.  
The radio was custom designed for Chrylser Auto in the 1940's by Philco.  When the United States entered the Second World War in 1941 civilian auto production was halted and Philco was left with thousands of these radios in stock.  Rather than scrap these models, in 1942 they put them into a cabnet speaker sold them as a sit-by radio.  The 8 tube reciever is has execllent selectiblity and the fullwave audio amplifer provided a linear output of a then impressive, 5 watts.

The design is meant to be place on a 3.2mm (3/32") thick glass plate cut to 32.9mmx111mm.  Clean the glass of any residue, cut and apply the vinyl mask.  Paint masked glass with gloss black emable paint.  Let partially dry and remove mask with a pin or dail.  Use laser cutter to cut a 32.9mmx111mm jig.  Place plate into jig and etch numbers, gradulations, and boarder frames.  Hand paint boarders and frames with silver paint.  Do not paint over the numbers or gradulations.

Bubble lights, we all love them but they have one obvious and annoying flaw, they use C7 nightlight bulbs which burn out leaving you with a dead bubble light despite the fact that the rest of the light is still good. Well no more! .. I am working on designing a serviceable bubble light base that if the bulb burns out, you can simply replace the burned out bulb for a new one, remove the old glass bubble stick and insert it into your new base and you are back in business!.  I do want to mention this version I dont have the screw mechanism in place so you would have to glue the top/bottom together for now.  Also I do want to caution with anything electric that also involves heat there maybe a fire hazard risk. USE AT YOUR OWN RISK!.. While I have tried to make sure there are sufficient ventilation holes there is always a chance if you use a higher watt bulb there could be too much heat generated and the plastic (depending on what you print it in could warp, soften or worse melt/catch on fire) so please use caution and don't leave this unattended without significant testing on your part first!)  This is still very much a "work in progress".  Also the color of the material you print in and/or the color bulb could generate more heat causing this model to melt so please proceed with caution and test-test-test.
I printed mine on a Craftbot using CraftUnique PLA white at 0.2mm
